Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Update System.IO.Packaging dependency" (#1231) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi together,

Would it be possible to update the System.IO.Packaging dependency to include the bug fix of https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/43012 ?

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Update System.IO.Packaging to 7.0.0" (#1393) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Opened pull request "update System.IO.Packaging to 7.0.0" (#1393) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Closed issue "Remove obsoleted APIs for v3.0" (#1272) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
A number of APIs have been obsoleted over the years. With the change to v3.0.0, we can remove these.

This is to track removing APIs that are currently obsolete - if we determine APIs should be removed for v3.0.0, those will be tracked separately

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Make part/package constructors internal" (#1392) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
We'll look at making these public again at some point (especially if people need them for some reason), but at the moment I don't think anyone would be overriding things since they have internal abstract methods. This will allow us to play around with their construction a bit more without requiring a public constructor we have to enable to work.

Fixes #1272

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Consider removing OpenXmlPackage.Close()" (#1298) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
There are two APIs that do the same thing: `Close()` and `Dispose()`. There is no need to have `Close()` as it is better to use the dispose pattern. Let's take v3.0 as a chance to remove this API and just use `Dispose()`.

- [ ] Remove `Close()` usage on `main`
- [x] Obsolete `Close()` on `release/2.20.0`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Make part/package constructors internal" (#1392) at dotnet/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody: We'll look at making these public again at some point (especially if people need them for some reason), but at the moment I don't think anyone would be overriding things since they have internal abstract methods. This will allow us to play around with their construction a bit more without requiring a public constructor we have to enable to work.
